headline: Homemade BBQ Sauce
description: This quick and easy homemade barbecue sauce has just the right mixture of sweetness and spice. Adjust seasoning to your personal taste.

video.description: This homemade BBQ sauce is a little bit sweet, a little bit spicy, and a whole lot delicious.
video.name: A Very Popular BBQ Sauce

name: Homemade BBQ Sauce

recipeInstructions.text: Combine brown sugar, ketchup, vinegar, water, and Worcestershire sauce in a blender. Season with mustard, paprika, salt, pepper, and hot pepper sauce. Blend until smooth.

review.reviewBody: This recipe needed some doctoring to get there, but was a decent starting point. I added an extra tsp of Worcestershire, 2 tbsp Molasses, 1/2 tsp garlic powder, 1/2 tsp onion powder, and used dark soy sauce instead of the salt and cider vinegar instead of red wine vinegar. Then I brought everything to a simmer until it thickened. Next time I'll also use less water and only 1 cup of sugar.
Absolutely incredible!! All I changed was more brown sugar and rinsed out 2 ketchup bottles with water, didn't add any more water. I left it heat thru, bubble a bit. Thick and sweet indeed
Added garlic, minced onions and more hot sauce so it wasn't overly sweet. It's really good.
So delicious! A smash hit with my entire family! I brushed it onto chicken drumsticks and used it for dipping. I will definitely be making this again.
This sauce came out great. Let it boil for 3-5 minutes then let it cool. If you use it while itâ€™s warm its consistency is more of a mop.

I didnâ€™t have a bottle bottle of my favorite so I use this recipe. Very easy to make and delicious. Per the Cookâ€™s note, to intensify the flavor, I did bring to a boil for one minute and then simmer for 30 before cooling and using it.

I added a tbsp of lemon juice, tsp onion powder, tsp black pepper. Then I brought it to a boil, lowered to simmer for 1 hour. Stir frequently. Cooled, put in jars and then the fridge.

Delicious. I recommend cooking so that the vinegar mellows up a bit. Made this a few times with various tweeks and love it. So do my kids!... I've used German mustard, liquid smoke, spicy date syrup, molasses, honey, and balsamic vinegar. Little Smokey's are killer with this recipe, as is.

The bomb. My son doesnâ€™t like BBQ sauce and he loved this. Made just as described with maaybe a touch more brown sugar. Oh & I threw it all together on the stove, whisked it and didnâ€™t burn it!! Thank you for a great recipe!!

I make this excellent BBQ sauce all the time, everyone loves it I always add extra hot sauce and a squeeze of yellow mustard As others have said, be sure to bring this to a boil on the stove; you won't be sorry

I love allrecipes. I'm dumfounded how this achieved 4 1/2 stars. It was as bland as ketchup. To make this plateable enough to eat I left out the water and the consistency was runny without the water. In the recommended measurements I used Smoked Paprika and Course Black Pepper. AND IT WAS BLAND. It tasted like ketchup. So, I added 1 Tsp Chili Powder 1 Tsp Cumin 1 Tsp Hickory-Flavored Liquid Smoke Flavoring 1/2 TSP Garlic Powder 1/$ TSP Onion Powder It was not "Great" but without these changes it was not edible

This is the best BBQ sauce I've ever had. I've ALWAYS used Bullseye Hickory Smoked sauce and this one is way better. Easy to make with the things most people have in their cupboards. I used smoked paprika for that smokey flavor and it did not disappoint. I strongly recommend you try it. Love this sauce!!
Delicious on ribs and steaks. I needed a good bbq sauce recipe.
Made this several for family and friends. I add about 1/4 cup of bourbon.
My family loved it! We have eaten nothing other than Sweet Baby Ray's barbque sauce for YEARS. My husband and a houseguest suggested I make this from now own. Thanks for the recipe!

This is a delicious recipe. I followed it as written and doubled it as I used it to based 5 pounds of rib tips. I have a review for the oven bake rib tips from the same website with pictures. The only adjustment I made is that I added a tablespoon of blackstrap molasses as I love the taste of molasses. I reduced the brown sugar by 1/2 cup and used coconut sugar instead. I did not taste the difference. I also added an extra tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce because I like the flavor of it. I saw where one reviewer added a dash of liquid smoke which I will do the next time. This is a delicious rich and thick (from boiling for 5-7 minutes. The flavors are enhanced from the boiling. After it cools I put it in a cleaned empty 32 oz squeeze ketchup bottle. My sister uses it to squeeze on tater tots and says itâ€™s the best. I will likely not buy bottled barbecue sauce again after I use up what I have on hand.

Preboiled the ribs a couple of minutes in salted water that had a few tbsp of apple cider vinegar. Used dry rub mixture with added brown sugar. Brushed on olive oil then covered with Al foil. Bake at 250 deg F for 2-3 hrs. Remove ribs and pour off the fat and water. Cover with sauce then loosely cover with foil - about 1/2 hr at 250 the lower to 200. Ribs come out moist and delicious. I substituted apple cider vinegar and used sriracha sauce (3 tsp).

It was good. I added a tad bit more ketchup and less salt and I didnâ€™t have any hot sauce. Iâ€™d cook it if I was going to use it at the table but it cooked and mellowed together nicely while on the chicken. Glad to have found this in a hurry when I realize my chicken was ready and I didnâ€™t have any store bought bottles. I might not buy any anymore since this so was so easy.
This is the best BBQ recipe I've ever tried. The flavor beats any bottled store-bought BBQ sauce I've tried in the past. This is definitely a keeper.
This is the best BBQ sauce I have ever tasted!
Great recipe, I substituted yellow mustard, 1tbsp. for ground mustard. Now, I can't stop barbequin'!
It was really good as posted---to suit our taste I added 1 tablespoon of molasses, and followed other reviewers suggestions to cook briefly. Outstanding.

Amazingâ€¦.. I thought this recipe would be too sweet, but was pleasantly surprised once I applied it to my ribs and barbecue baked beans. I did have to substitute a few things because I didnâ€™t have some of the things on hand. I used white vinegar, prepared yellow mustard (1 & 1/2 T.) steak sauce to replace the Worcester sauce, and bbq rub to replace the paprika, salt, & pepper. I simmered the sauce for an hour on low heat and then apply to my ribs and barbecue baked beans and baked them in the oven for an hour and a halfâ€¦. wow, delicious, yummy!
Way, way, way too sweet!
My family liked it so much itâ€™s becoming a regular Mark W
I love it, I just omitted the water, fantastic ðŸ¥°ðŸ¥°ðŸ¥° Thank you for the recipe.
I made it and just cut back to one cup of brown sugar. It was so good I made another batch the next day! I did heat it on the stove though.
I added 2 tablespoons of honey for 1 batch, then for another batch I added a few drops of hickory flavored liquid smoke. love them both!
Super easy! I made this in a pinch -it only took me like 5 minutes. I really like the flavor! I added some maple smokehouse steak seasoning to jazz it up.
Best BBQ sauce ever!!! I added a little pineapple juice and coconut water. Awesome suace!!!!
I was ready tomake a quick dinner and needed bbq sce. Well, this was awesome! I also added some "garlic"... Thank you, you saved the day!
I liked this recipe. Very straightforward and tasty. I cooked it for a few minutes to marry the flavors and thicken it up a bit. Will definitely make again.

The vinegar taste is overwhelming, in my opinion. I didn't like it, neither did my husband. Diddn't know how to counterbalance the vinegar taste, added some ketchup but still too much vinegar was ruining the tasts.

Definitely boil the sauce, I had to discard the first batch because it was way too much red wine vinegar. The second batch, I used 1/4 of the recipe amount and added some liquid smoke. Tasted fantastic!
Simple, easy, and tasty...

I tried making this recipe as stated and was not impressed. It was way too sweet with no depth of flavor and a bit thin for my liking. So I made the following changes for an upgraded version: reduced brown sugar to 3/4 cup (dark brown) and reduce water from 1/2 cup to a few tablespoons. I also sauteed some diced yellow onion, garlic and serrano pepper in a pan and added it to the mixture. I then simmered everything together on low heat and used an immersion blender to get rid of the chunks.
Delicious! I didn't make any changes and loved it.

This is a very versatile sauce. I've made it several times. My husband hates bottled sauces, but he really loves this. You can half the recipe, change up the spices or sugar how you like. We use Scirocco for the hot sauce. I brown country style ribs, throw them in crockput on high, and last hour add this sauce. Very tasty!
I wen exactly by the measurements and this was terrific. Flavor - Check; Consistency Check. Made crock-pot pork chops and they were wonderful. This may be my go-to sauce, Yum

Substituted apple cider vinegar 1:1 because itâ€™s what I had on-hand. And Whey Low Sweetener for the sugar 1:1, because I have diabetes. It was delicious!! Used with beef ribs and they came out great.

However, my changes are:
1/3 less sugar
1/2 MORE vinegar
a bit more spice
(I use garlic salt as well)

This is a GREAT base recipe. Keep in mind it's easily adaptable to personal preference. I keep coming back, but every batch is a bit different :)

Tastes great! I found this last minute after I made pulled pork for dinner but forgot we were out of bbq sauce! I did not have red wine vinegar, so subbed apple cider vinegar with some honey. I did not have dry mustard, so subbed regular prepared mustard. It still tasting great. I'm ready to have the actual ingredients so I can try it again!
The recipe is way too complicated and contains way to many ingredients.

This is one great sauce recipe! I used apple cider vinegar because I did not have the red wine vinegar, but I honestly can't imagine that it would have been any better with the red wine vinegar. Oh, and I did cook it on the stove for a few minutes and then let it cool before using it in the recipe. We used the remaining sauce on the ribs after they came out from under the broiler. Yum!
I made this and put it on smoked ribs throughout the smoking process. It was one of the most flavorful slabs of ribs that I have ever made. Making 4 racks, they didn't last long.

This recipe was a big hit in my house! I used it on pork ribs and now I was asked by my kids to never use anything else for bbq sauce!! Iâ€™m not sure why others said to cook it.. bbq sauce is supposed to be ooey and gooey besides it cooks when you put it on your meats so why would I add work to my dinner? Thank you so much for this recipe

Itâ€™s a great base but is far too sweet for me. If you love really sweet sauces, youâ€™ll love this sauce and probably not want to make changes - provided you also like vinegar. Iâ€™ll try again using less sugar and maybe even use tomato sauce in place of ketchup. The vinegar is on the upper end of the spectrum, though I like vinegar-based sauces, so it is fine for me in that sense.

I took a risk of adding a teaspoon each of garlic and onion powder to dial up the flavor a bit. These turned out to be great additions. The sauce is probably fine without them, however.

I use white pepper in place of black pepper in sauces because it keeps the sauce smooth and free of specks. The flavor profile is pretty close the same and probably impossible for most people to tell the difference. It just takes less white pepper because it is ground so fine.

As for cooking, simmering for a while is a must. I brought the sauce to just below a boil and backed off the heat and let it simmer gently for an hour. Be sure to whisk or stir constantly during the initial heating and periodically thereafter. This stuff will get gummy and burn if left alone on high heat.
4 stars foe a good base but lacked some items. I added garlic powder, onion powder, and honey and let it marinate overnight.
it's our favorite! we make it every time we barbecue. my family won't let me buy bottled barbecue sauce anymore.
This is wonderful! Had to sub ground mustard w/ regular mustard (used 1 tablespoon).. Hubby even liked it.. TY
Kinda sweet, so I just added more vinegar and franks hot sauce
I make this sauce regularly. I use apple cider vinegar, and sometimes I add cayenne pepper. I always cook this until it thickens.

This was an "exceptional" and simple economicalsauce.
Simple flavor, I used a non-High Fructose ketchup. following the recipe exactly for my first batch, I did warm it my the stovetop and the smell was mouth watering! When preparing my second batch I added 1 tbsp of soy sauce, 1tsp of powdered ginger and 1/2 tsp of cumin.
Overall, this a great go to for me. I will no longer purchase bottled BBQ Sauces.
Thanks for a great recipe.

Delicious! Jeremy suggestions made total sense to me do I went right to his modified version: increase Worstashire to 1/2 cup, substitute 1 tsp ground cayenne for dashes of hot sauce, add garlic, simmer. Sweet and spicy--great!

I made this sauce to add to a pork butt that I had made in the crock pot to give it more flavor. It really did the trick. Everyone raved about the barbecue and I think the sauce is what made it. I followed the recipe but changed the paprika to smoked paprika. I added a small amount of liquid smoke. I read others reviews and I did not put it in the blender but boiled it for about a minute to let the flavors come together. The next day I let it get hot in the crock pot and then kept it on warm which also blended all the flavors. This will be my go to recipe for barbecue sauce.
I followed all
This is way too sweet, cooked or not. Not my fav.

This sace is great! I'm 13 and when my mom asked me to make bbq sauce for our ribs, I totally freaked. I thought, what'll be good that won't take FOREVER??? But then I found this recipe and was like woah. All I have to do is chuck it all in the blender? I even read it a few times to make sure I wasn't missing something. My family and I loved it and this is now our go-to recipe for bbq sauce. Perfect amount of sweetness and spice for me. Just a quick note, we didn't have any red wine vinegar, so I used equal parts apple cider vinegar and red wine. Macy, you might want to try this if you found that there was too much vinegar for you. I'm not a huge vinegar fan myself, and the way I did it wasn't very vinegary. Anyway, it was delicious. THANK YOU @JRNEUMILLER!!!!

I'm cutting back on sodium so I made a personal amount for myself while the family used the store bought stuff. Since it's just for me I only used a splash of vinegar, and 1/4 of everything here in a pot on very low heat and added more to taste as needed. My Mom would say you can always add but not take away, so if you're unsure, reduce vinegar, worcesthire etc, and add more as needed. I also added a smigde of olive oil. Tastes better heated as others have said.
Just perfect as is! I do cook it like some others have suggested.
Definitely a favorite for our pulled pork sandwiches.
NO changes it was GREAT. Wife loved it.
Make ahead to allow flavors to meld. Also consider cooking it first for awile.
This barbecue sauce is amazing and so easy!
Very good sauce. Easy to tweak to individual tastes. This is now on my favorite list.

This was very easy to make, I made it in the microwave very quickly. The flavor is good, although I would increase the vinegar to give it a bit more tang and definitely decrease the amount of sugar, because it was overpoweringly sweet.
very good!
Loved it!!!!
Good. I liked it. I didn't add the water, but still turned out well.

Just like others have said, no more bottled sauce for us! I tweak this recipe depending on my mood and what Iâ€™m cooking. I do heat the sauce to meld the flavors a bit. Thanks for the awesome recipe!
It's great! also - its better with cayenne instead of hot sauce, honey, Apple cider vinegar (in place of red wine vinegar) and juice from half a lemon.
Liked it but was a little sweet. And I used sugar free catsup. Will reduce the brown sugar next time. Was very good on pulled pork, and quick and easy to make.

I will NEVER buy bbq sauce again
It was delicious
Took minutes to make
I did cook for about 5 min before brushing on my ribs
I thought it was a nice balance of sweet and hot
Thank you for a great reciepe

I started with this "as is" but found it is very sweet. Maybe it is a Canadian thing but I like my bbq sauce a little less sweet and a bit smokey similar to Bulls Eye Hickory. So after tasting this as per the recipe, I threw it in a pot and heated it, added some chili powder, more salt, more hot sauce (used Franks Red) and found the added saltiness and heat to balance out the sugar, then added probably a good teaspoon or more of liquid hickory smoke. It ended up way more to our personal tastes. I love this recipe as it is a great base to personalize from. Like other recommendations, if you don't like sweet sauces probably just reduce the amount of sugar or ketchup. If you make it as is and it isn't quite right, experiment with it. Thank you for posting it! It saved me another last minute trip to the grocery store.
Excellent! Even better, simple!
nice recipe...easy and a good mix of sweet andn spicy
Very good. Easy. Used only 1 cup packed brown sugar

My family and I loved this BBQ Sauce over pork ribs (seasoned with garlic, salt & pepper and baked at 350Â°F for 1.5 hours covered w/aluminum foil, then added the BBQ sauce and returned to the oven for 30 more minutes - the last 20 uncovered). For the BBQ sauce: I used a little less sugar and cayenne pepper instead of the paprika since I did not have the latter. I also omitted the hot sauce. I will never buy a BBQ Sauce thanks to this!
I ended up heating the sauce to caramelize the sugars. I thought it improved the flavor.

Delish! I made a few changes just due to not having enough ingredients: added some tomato paste, molasses, ghost pepper honey, and white pepper but I can see that it would have been great just as written. Made this for oven baked BBQ ribs, everyone loved it! Next time I'll make it exactly and update.

I took other suggestions and heated it on the stove. It tastes great! The only change I made was not having quite enough red rice vinegar and making up the difference (about a couple tablespoons) of cider vinegar. I am definitely saving this recipe!
Great sauce after cooking. Iâ€™ll be halving the amount of sugar next time. Was too sweet for me but great sauce none the less.
Excellent sauce. Cook all ingredients though. I brought to a boil and simmered for 15 minutes. Then I blended in the blender. It really brings out and blends the flavors.

This is a very good recipe. 
 I also a member the simmer society - I did so, following suggestions from a few submissions..... 

Thank You all.
Way too sweet. I added more acv, garlic and a teaspoon of blackstrap molasses.

This sauce recipe is designed by the gods.. my family made bland ribs for a bbq. They needed some love... so I raced to the world wide web for a worthy recipe... hizzahhh, i came across this ambrosia and mixed the ribs and sauce in a slow cooker on low for 1 hr. Heaven just pure heaven. Thankkkkkkks

As has been mentioned, this is a better sauce if cooked, but it is very good if you do. Also the red wine vinegar can be overwhelming for some, I swapped out for apple cider vinegar for the second batch and it let the other flavours come through more, but it doesn't have the same sharpness to it. That tanginess can help balance the sweetness if you've low and slow bbq'd the ribs with a sugar-based rub.
Great on chicken legs! Used pinch of cayenne since I did have hot pepper. Worked fine.
Easy quick and super flavorful. Loved the tang from the vinegar and well balance with the brown sugar. I may add more heat next time.
I added 3 chipotle in adobo and used oriental hot mustard. Turned out great!

Overall, definitely a keeper! I adjusted amount for 12 servings since we don't eat a lot of BBQ sauce. It was enough for one rack of ribs with extra. 

I followed the recipe exactly but had to add 1 more tablespoon of brown sugar because the vinegar was too strong. So, next time, accounting for the same 12 servings, I will start with 1 1/2 Tablespoons of red wine vinegar and taste before adding more.

I make this regularly and always have some on hand. Never had a complaint. I do modify a bit and double the Worcestershire sauce and add way more hot sauce. Tapatio seams to be the best. and add some cayenne pepper for a lingering spice.
I made the recipe exactly how it was written and it was delicious! not only did I love it but my boyfriend loved it also!

I gave a four star because I cut back on the brown sugar (full recipe would have made it too sweet) and because I was using it for BBQ hot wings I ramped up the hot sauce. I ended up by using 1\2 cup of brown sugar and 8 teaspoons of Frank's original hot sauce. I also simmered it for 1 minute which thickened the sauce and enhanced the flavors. I have been trying to do d a recipe that mimics the wing sauce from my favorite wing estaurant. This recipe is the closest I have ever gotten. When my husband gets home I will ask him what he thinks and I may bump up the hot sauce a bit more. Really good. Better then any bottled sauce out there!
